		Question: who was saint paul the apostle
		Answer:
answer: Saint Paul the Apostle was a Christian missionary who spread the teachings of Jesus Christ throughout the Roman Empire. He was born Saul of Tarsus, a Jewish man who was a Roman citizen. He was a Pharisee, a strict sect of Judaism, and he persecuted the early Christians. However, after a vision of Jesus Christ, he converted to Christianity and became one of the most important figures in the early Church. He wrote many of the letters that are included in the New Testament, and he is considered to be one of the most influential figures in the history of Christianity.
